awd_titl_txt: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Determining anucleated sperm function in Lepidoptera
awd_abstract_narration:
The function of sperm cells is traditionally thought to be a way for males to transfer DNA to eggs and create offspring. Sperm cells that do not carry DNA cannot fertilize an egg, thus the existence of such sperm cells in butterflies and moths is puzzling. Almost all of these insects make two types of sperm: both traditional, DNA-bearing sperm, and a second type that lacks DNA. In all of these cases, males make far more of this DNA-lacking sperm than traditional sperm. The sheer abundance of this sperm type implies it plays some yet-unknown functional role in reproduction. This proposal aims to uncover the evolutionary significance of these DNA-lacking sperm cells. The research will also aid in the development of technologies that will allow scientists to maintain important genetically modified lineages in a way that is both cheaper and less vulnerable to failure than traditional rearing methods. Such protocols could even be extended to threatened species to create a gene bank. Outreach to the public will occur via summer science workshops.

Production of multiple sperm types by a single male has independently arisen in many animal lineages. In all well-studied cases, evidence suggests that only one type of sperm retains its ability to fertilize eggs but the function of these non-fertilizing sperm remains unclear. Nowhere is this more apparent than in butterflies and moths; males of this order produce a secondary sperm type that lacks nuclear DNA. These anucleated cells represent a significant investment for a male, outnumbering their nucleated sperm by 20-to-1, but cannot possibly fertilize eggs to directly increase male fitness. Several hypotheses have been proposed since the discovery of anucleated sperm to explain the existence of anucleated sperm, but to-date no rigorous tests have been undertaken. This project will develop and refine artificial insemination protocols in two lepidopteran species that differ in mating strategy in order to thoroughly test the function of anucleated sperm in different selective backgrounds with a common framework.

por.por_cntn:
This research aimed to better understand an enduring mystery of reproductive biology: why do butterflies and moths make non-fertilizing sperm?

 

Sperm are often thought of as single-purpose cells designed to deliver DNA to an egg and thus form a new organism. However, male butterflies and moths challenge this paradigm. These insects make both fertilizing sperm and a second type that lacks DNA and cannot fertilize an egg. Perplexingly, these non-fertilizing sperm are a common feature across almost every species studied and appear to be produced in a controlled, predictable way. In other words, they are not merely failed fertilizing sperm, but a unique reproductive trait in butterflies and moths. Non-fertilizing sperm have been variously suggested to be guides for fertilizing sperm, nutrient gifts to the female, or sacrificial combatants in sperm competition. But despite decades of hypothesized functions, non-fertilizing sperm function has received little evaluation with modern methodologies.

 

Our research sought to test these hypotheses with cutting edge techniques. Initially, we planned to use manipulative artificial insemination experiments to assess non-fertilizing sperm function, but in the process of protocol development it became clear that non-sperm reproductive proteins from males play a key role in fertilization success and could not be easily disentangled from the sperm themselves with our methods. As such, we refocused on using tests of molecular evolution to discern non-fertilizing sperm function from the patterns of selection on this trait.

 

To do so, we compared the evolution of genes expressed in sperm of two species: the monarch butterfly, Danaus plexippus, and the Carolina sphinx moth, Manduca sexta. We showed that genes expressed in fertilizing sperm evolve more adaptively in the species with higher sperm competition, the monarch, as expected. Genes expressed in non-fertilizing sperm, however, do not evolve differently under differing sperm competition pressures. In other words, they are unlikely to be agents of sperm competition. This work marked the first true test and refutation of this hypothesis and has been published in a peer reviewed journal as well as relayed at several international scientific meetings.

 

In order to make these comparisons, we contributed substantially to the genomic resources for the agricultural pest, Manduca sexta. We completed the first whole-genome resequencing of wild-caught individuals, which will be valuable to understanding natural variation for pest management. These data are now publicly available and have already been used to answer the relatedly evolutionary reproductive biology question of how adaptively sex chromosomes evolve in these moths.

 

Later in the award period, we observed previously undescribed reproductive biology of a bagworm moth, Thyridopteryx ephemeraeformis. Males of this species appear to make few or no non-fertilizing sperm and thus present a rare exception to the norm in moths. We have recently generated sequencing data to assemble the genome and annotate the genes of this moth to compare with other species. The data and results of this investigation are still forthcoming but will be made publicly available when complete.

 

More broadly, the butterflies and moths reared for this research were used in outreach teaching with local Girl Scouts to promote science education. We assessed the effectiveness of these outreach events to change attitudes towards insects in a peer reviewed article. This research also supported the dissertation work of one PhD student who mentored five undergraduates to develop independent, related projects on butterfly and moth biology. Three of these five, as well as the PhD student, traveled to conferences to present the findings of their work.  One of these independent projects is already published as part of the larger molecular investigation of sperm gene evolution described above.

 

In summary, this award advanced knowledge on understudied reproductive biology, generated new genomic resources for a pest species, and supported the professional development of several early career students.
